division.name: main

section.title: Introduction
section.name: intro
section.blockquote: IntAct is a protein interaction database and analysis system. It provides a query interface and modules to analyse interaction data. This manual describes the IntAct data structure and the components of the IntAct system.

section.title: Recent changes
section.name: new
section.blockquote:
Changes up to February 28, 2006 :
New Advanced search added.
New InterPro search added.
In addition to the user manual, a dedicated curation manual has been released.

Changes up to January 01, 2005 :
New Search user interface available.
New IntAct API tutorial.
Integration of data including features (eg.
Goehler et al. ).
Integration of IntAct data into UniProt
IntAct takes part in the IMEx consortium
New application ( MiNe ) allowing to find the minimal connecting network given a set of proteins.
New application ( Targets ) to predict targets for pull-down experiments.

Changes up to February 01, 2004 :
IntAct release 1: IntAct data is now available in PSI MI XML format , see the download section. Controlled vocabularies are available in GO DAG format.
20672 interactions have been imported from Giot et al, 2003. The dataset contains extensive crosslinking to UniProt, GO, InterPro, and FlyBase.

section.name: download
section.title: Download
section.blockquote:
IntAct data is available in PSI MI XML format . Each IntAct release is split into multiple XML files according to the pattern Species_name-[small | exeriment-name].xml. For example, s-cerevisiae_small.xml contains data on all small-scale experiments in S.cerevisiae stored in IntAct, s-cerevisiae_ho-2002.xml contains the data from the Ho et al, 2002 experiment. The current release is available at
ftp://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/databases/intact/current/xml/ .

section.name: CVS
section.title: Controlled Vocabularies
section.blockquote:
To ensure data consistency, IntAct makes intensive use of controlled vocabularies. All controlled vocabularies are available in Gene Ontology DAG-Edit format and HTML format. Some IntAct annotation of controlled vocabulary terms do not fit the GO DAG-Edit format, but as we want to export all available information, some comments might have to be filtered out from the *.def files before editing them in GO DAG-Edit. For an overview and download of IntAct controlled vocabularies, see
ftp://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/databases/intact/current/cv/ .

section.title: Common elements
section.name: CommonElements
section.blockquote: All main IntAct objects have the following attributes:

section.title: ac
section.name: BasicObject.ac
section.blockquote:
The accession number. This is a unique, stable identifier for an object. The same accession number will always be associated with the same object. To reference IntAct objects from outside, accession numbers should be used. The format of the accession number is one or more uppercase letters, followed by a dash, followed by a number.
In regular expression syntax: [A-Z0-9]+\-[0-9]+
Example: EBI-15

section.title: shortlabel
section.name: AnnotatedObject.shortLabel
section.blockquote:
The name is a short, concise name to identify an object. Names for proteins are usually UniProt IDs, names for experiments are usually: author-year-number .
author being the name of the first author of the associated publication. That author name can be truncated if too long.
year being the year of the publication.
number maybe be used in case we create multiple experiments related to one publication.
names for interactions are usually the name of gene1 'hyphen' name of gene2.
Names will normally be stable, but they may change, e.g. when the gene name of a protein is changed by the relevant nomenclature body, e.g. HUGO. Names are not guaranteed to be unique, e.g. if two proteins have the same primary gene name. They are guaranteed to be unique for controlled vocabulary terms within each controlled vocabulary. All names are in lowercase.
Example for a protein: got2_yeast.

section.title: fullName
section.name: AnnotatedObject.fullName
section.blockquote:
The full name of the object.
Example: Aspartate aminotransferase.

section.title: Xref
section.name: AnnotatedObject.Xref
section.blockquote:
Crossreferences to other databases. A crossreference has the following attributes:
Name :The name of the external database.
Primary id : The primary id or accession number of the object in the external database.
Secondary id : The secondary id of the object in the external database.
Crossreference type : The type of crossreference.

section.title: Annotation
section.name: AnnotatedObject.Annotation
section.blockquote: Each object may have one or more annotations associated with it. Each annotation has a topic, which broadly classifies the annotation, and the annotation text.

section.title: created
section.name: BasicObject.created
section.blockquote: The date the object has been created.

section.title: updated
section.name: BasicObject.updated
section.blockquote: The date the object has been updated last.

section.title: Main objects
section.name: mainObject
section.blockquote:
IntAct has the following main objects:
Experiment
Interaction
Interactor
Example (simplified): Representation of the Interleukin 2 receptor binding: One interaction object represents the complex of the alpha, beta, and gamma chains which form the receptor. This interaction object is then used in the second interaction object, in which the binding of Interleukin 2 to the receptor is represented. Both Interaction objects are linked to an experiment, in which the Interaction has been determined.
The following section describes the main objects in detail.

section.title: Experiment
section.name: Experiment
section.blockquote:
An Experiment object describes an experiment which has been performed to generate one or more interactions. It indicates the conditions in which the experiment has been performed. The description broadly classifies the experiment, it does not aim at providing all the necessary data to repeat the experiment. The attributes of the Experiment are the
BioSource
The biological system in which the interaction took place in the experiment.
identificationMethod
The experimental method by which the molecules participating in the interaction have been detected.
Example: Mass spectrometry.
interactionMethod
The experimental method by which the interaction has been detected.
Example: yeast two hybrid.
Each Experiment provides a list of one or more Interactions which have been determined by this Experiment. One Experiment might contain a single Interaction, or many hundreds for large scale experiments.

section.title: Interaction
section.name: Interaction
section.blockquote:
The Interaction object describes the interaction of two or more Interactors (proteins). As the number of Interactors in an Interaction is not limited, an Interaction can describe both binary interactions, which are the result of for example yeast two hybrid experiments, and interactions with more than two Interactors, for example determined by "TAP" experiments. The attributes of an Interaction are
CvInteractionType A description of the type of interaction.
Example: association.
kD The dissociation constant.

section.title: Interactor
section.name: Interactor
section.blockquote:
A molecule or complex participating in an Interaction. The only direct attribute of an Interactor is
BioSource
The biological system in which the interactor normally is found. For a human protein, the BioSource would be "Human", even if it has been expressed in E.coli in a particular experiment.
If the Interactor is a Protein, it additionally has the attributes
sequence The amino acid sequence of the protein. crc64 The CRC64 checksum for the amino acid sequence. This checksum is used to quickly detect if the amino acid sequence has changed, for example during an update process. It is also used to check if the amino acid sequence has potentially been corrupted.
The algorithm to compute the CRC64 is described in the ISO 3309 standard. The generator polynomial is x64 + x4 + x3 + x + 1.
Reference: Press W.H., Flannery B.P., Teukolsky S.A. and Vetterling W.T. "Numerical recipes in C", 2nd ed., pp896-902, Cambridge University Press (1993). (See http://www.ulib.org/webRoot/Books/Numerical_Recipes/bookcpdf/c20-3.pdf) It should be noted that while, in theory, two different sequences could have the same CRC64 value, the likelihood that this would happen is extremely low.
An Interactor describes an "abstract" form of e.g. a protein, similar to a description in a protein sequence database. One protein can participate in many interactions. To describe the specific conditions in which an Interactor participates in an Interaction, the following additional attributes are used:
stoichiometry The number of units of this interactor which participate in the interaction. The default is one.
expressedIn A BioSource object which describes the biological system in which the protein has been expressed.
Example: If a human protein has been expresed in E.coli, expressedIn would refer to E.coli.
Role The role of the Interactor in the Interaction. In a yeast two hybrid experiment, each Interaction would usually have an Interactor which has the role "bait" and another one which has the role "prey".
Features The Features record the properties of the molecule that is involved in the interaction.
An Interactor is normally a protein. However, to model hierarchical assemblies of complexes from subcomplexes, an Interactor can also be an Interaction.
Example: To model a receptor-ligand interaction, the receptor could be modeled by an interaction which describes the composition of the receptor from its component proteins. Then, in another Interaction, the association of receptor and ligand would be described. See the IL-2 example .

section.title: Auxiliary objects
section.name: AuxiliaryObjects
section.blockquote: The following objects are auxiliary objects, often used in several different main classes.

section.title: BioSource
section.name: BioSource
section.blockquote:
The BioSource object describes a biological system, usually a species. The attributes of a BioSource are
taxId The NCBI tax id, see the NCBI taxonomy server or the NEWT taxonomy server .
Technical note : We are using a programatical access to the Newt server to create on-the-fly new BioSources in IntAct.
shortLabel The shortLabel is the UniProt OS code, where available. fullName The full name is the scientific name of the species. tissue (optional)
The tissue is the tissue type used in the experiment. compartment (optional)
The compartment is the cellular compartment in which the interaction has been shown to occur. cell type (optional)
The cell type is the cell line in which the interaction is shown to occur.

section.title: CvObject
section.name: CvObject
section.blockquote: IntAct makes intensive use of controlled vocabularies. Where possible, data attributes are controlled vocabularies, the terms are selected from a defined list instead of being free text. For each attribute which is selected from a controlled vocabulary, a specific CvXXXXX class exists, for example CvInteractionType. Each term in a controlled vocabulary has a definition, usually has crossreferences, and may have additional comments.

section.title: Features
section.name: FEATURES_HELP_SECTION
section.blockquote:
The attributes of the individual protein molecules involved in the interaction are recorded as features of the proteins. This includes information such as the range of amino acids involved in the interaction, tagging of the protein molecule, mutations in the sequence etc.
Controlled vocabulary is used for determining the feature type and feature identification method. The features are then displayed in search as an autogenerated sentence. Additional crossreferences in the features also give information about the structure and domains in the proteins.

division.section:
IntAct provides a number of applications. Depending on the installation you are using, some modules described here may not be available, or additional modules not described in this manual might be available.
general search
http://www.ebi.ac.uk/intact/search/do/search?searchString=
<query.string>
<query.string>
is the user query that the searched object should match.
Wildcards are supported.
it can be either:
AC
shortlabel
fullname
Xref (UniProt, GO, FlyBase, SGD, Interpro...)
Alias (gene name, locus, orf ...)
Known partners of a protein
http://www.ebi.ac.uk/intact/search/do/search?searchString=
<protein>
<protein>
should be either the AC, shortlabel, alias or Xref (eg. UniProt ID) of a Protein.
Wildcards are supported.
Binary interactions
http://www.ebi.ac.uk/intact/search/do/search?binary=
<protein1>
,
<protein2>
This URL will give you all the binary interactions for two given proteins contained within IntAct. There are cases when
<protein1>
and
<protein2>
will be the same, for example in the case of a homodimer or when an interaction is demonstrated between different modified forms of the same protein (e.g. Flag-tagged and wild-type).
<protein1>
and
<protein2>
should be either the AC, shortlabel, alias or Xref (eg. UniProt ID) of a Protein.
Wildcards are supported but we encourage you to give a specific protein descriptor.
The search application currently allows a text-based search by entering a text string into the search text box. It is possible to obtain information on experiments, protein interactions, the proteins themselves and the controlled vocabulary , with various views used to display the data. Intact uses the concept of shortlabel which is intended to provide a way of 'more memorable identification' compared to an accession number (ac) , although searches by ac are obviously allowed. For example a particular Experiment may have an ac of EBI-12, but its name is 'gavin-2002' indicating a more meaningful reference to the physical experiment which the entry represents. Basic points on usage:
Wildcard searching is supported - for example matches will be retrieved for strings such as EBI*, *BI-14, E*4, etc etc. Though if too many result match your expression, you will be given some statistics about how many objects have matched your query and you will be asked to refine your query. cf. screenshot .
upper or lower case strings are acceptable (but not mixed case) and will be matched if they exist. The exception to this is a search by alias (ie gene name, as defined in UniProt) - currently these are stored as lower case and are searched for as such. This will become more sophisticated as the project matures.
currently searches are looking for four main types of objects: experiment, interaction, protein, and controlled vocabulary term (that has many sub types).
A search doesn't progress in a certain order as it used to be, we perform a global search on all mentionned types and if several of them match your query, a summary page will be displayd to give you an overview. That way, you can select the object you want to see amongst many types. cf screenshot .
At a lower level, specific attributes are searched by AC , shortlabel , fullname Xref (Uniprot AC, GO, SGD, FlyBase, Interpro...), and finally alias (gene, locus and orf name).
Note that whilst controlled vocabulary term (also called CvObject) details can be displayed via the click of a link, currently it is not possible to search for CvObjects via the text box search entry point.
The basic layout of the main results page follows the structure below:
An example result screen when searching for an Experiment is shown below:
An other example result screen when searching for an Experiment, this time there are too many interactions to display it in one go. So, the Experiment is splited in several pages that you can reach using the index above the Experiment.
This is shown below:
An example result screen when searching for an Interaction is shown below, as you can see the interaction is shown in the context of its experiment:
An example result screen when submiting a query that matches too many results, we show some basic statistics:
An example result screen when submiting a query that matches different types of objects, if there are not too many of them, we show simpler version of them to allow the user to choose:
Protein views can be of various types. Searching for a protein will result in a so-called 'binary view'. This view shows the list of proteins which are in a pairwise interaction with the searched-for protein.
The column "number of interactions" indicates:
a) for the query protein (first row), in how many distinct interactions it has been observed.
b) for all interactors of the query protein (subsequent rows), in how many interactions the current protein (current row) and the query protein (first row) interact.
An example result screen for this view is shown below:
Viewing the interactions involved for a particular (couple of) protein can also be done from the binary view by clicking on the interaction count.
The details for an individual protein are displayed as below:
If for example in the above screen you click on 'UniProt', this will display the controlled vocabulary information for the database identified with a name of 'UniProt'. The screen looks like this:
Note : You can see on that view that the CvDatabase called UniProt has been annotated using Xref, some of them have a special role in the IntAct framework:
search-url : is used to forward to the original source of the object. In the case of 'UniProt', if a protein has such a Uniprot Xref attached, the search application would automatically generate a link to allow you to view that same protein on the UniProt web site.
eg . Let search-url of the CvDatabase 'UniProt' be http://www.ebi.uniprot.org/entry/${ac}
Let the primaryId of that Xref be
P12345
, the search interface would replace ${ac} by
P12345
and the URL in the search application would show up as: http://www.ebi.uniprot.org/entry/
P12345
search-url-ascii : is used for programatical access to that database. In the case of UniProt, if a protein has such a Uniprot Xref attached, we can then get the UniProt FlatFile content correcponding to that protein.
eg . Let search-url-ascii of the CvDatabase 'UniProt' be http://www.ebi.uniprot.org/entry/${ac}?format=text&ascii
Let the primaryId of that Xref be
P12345
, the search interface would replace ${ac} by
P12345
and the URL in the search application would show up as: http://www.ebi.uniprot.org/entry/
P12345
?format=text&ascii
Protein names are links you can click to get a view of the protein details. Also each protein name has a term in superscript which denotes the role that the protein plays in the interaction. These terms have tooltips associated with them to display the role name, and also the term is a clickable link from which you can view the full details of the controlled vocabulary term which presents the controlled vocabulary information for that term (eg the details held to define the meaning of the term 'bait').
Since the items displayed for a search result include many items not actually queried for, the items that matched the original search string are
highlighted in red
. Specifically the *names* of the matching items are highlighted, since these are always displayed in every view.
Where a protein (for example) might actually occur more than once in an experiment, the display is rationalised to avoid multiple presentations of the same experiment - therefore all occurrences within an experiment are gathered together into one experiment view.
At the bottom of the page are a number of buttons:
a Graph button to display a graph of any selected proteins or interactions, which can be chosen by clicking the appropriate checkboxes.
a Path button to compute the minimal connecting network (using MiNe ) of the set of protein you have selected using the tickboxes. It then displays a graph (using hierarchView ) showing the computed path. The computed path is highlighted by coloring the interaction in red along the path.
a Interpro button to show the InterPro domain architecture for selected Proteins (using InterProSearch ).
a Select all button to check all tickboxes.
a Clear all button to uncheck all tickboxes.
The URL to access the editor is dependent upon the server where the editor is installed. The general format to access the editor takes the form of: http://server/intact/search/do/initAdvSearch.
Before going into any further details you should notice that the AdvancedSearch page is vertically split within two parts. On the left hand side there is the real advancedSearch where you can define your request. On the right hand side there is a relevant example to help you using the advancedSearch :
The advanced Search permits you to search for a specific object thus to choose what you want to see in your result page. Here are the objects you can ask for :
Controlled Vocabulary Term
Experiment
Interaction
Protein
You can also search for any object.
After selecting which object you are searching for, you define the creterii which will be used for the request. Depending on the object you choosed to display and on your desire, you can define 1 or several of the following fields :
The Accession Number
The Short Label
The Description
A crossresference to an other database
An annotation topic
The method used to determine the interaction (Interaction detection, for Experiment only)
The method used to determine the participants in the interaction (Participant detection, for Experiment only)
The interaction type (for Interaction only)
If you decide to define several of the fields (ex : Accession Number and Description) you can tell the advanced Search whether you want the objects to match all the define fields or only one of the fields in selecting either "all of the above (and)" box or "any of the above (or)" box.
If you choose to display any object you will obtain the same page then if you were doing a normal search :
If you choosed to display Controlled Vocabularies Term, the result page will follow the structure below:
If you choosed to display Experiments, the result page will follow the structure below:
If you choosed to display Interactions, the result page will follow the structure below:
If you choosed to display Proteins, the result page will follow the structure below:
The following paragraph explains how to link from IntAct to InterPro to visualise the protein domain architecture of IntAct proteins.
Within the IntAct search interface, proteins and interactions can be selected by clicking the relevant tickbox.
If an interaction is selected, all participating proteins will be considered selected. Once a protein set has been selected, the "InterPro" button on the top or bottom of the page can be clicked.
The IntAct Search Page with red circles around a tickbox and the InterPro button.
After a short waiting time,
you will then be forwarded to the InterPro page showing the domain architecture for the selected proteins.
The editor is a web based tool to edit objects in the IntAct database.
The application to edit IntAct database is only available for users with write access to it.
The URL to access the editor is dependent upon the server where the editor is installed. The general format to access the editor takes the form of:
http://server/intact[test|prod]/editor, where the server part may contain a port depending upon the configuration of the web server. For example, http://www.ebi.ac.uk/interpro/internal-tools/intacttest/editor is the URL to access the internal EBI test editor. The purpose of the test version is for testing and is shown in different color scheme to distinguish it from the production version. All the figures in this document refers to the color scheme of the production editor.
To use the editor, you must have a valid account to access the Intact database. The user is presented with a login screen as shown below:
Failure to login with a valid account results in the following error display:
The user is presented with the following screen after a successful login:
In the bottom left corner of the above screen, shows the login name (smudali) and the database (zpro) the editor is using. The footer shows the last modified date (usually, the build date).
This list defines the types available for edit. Before proceeding with any action (search or create), you must select an appropriate type first.
The IntAct type list defaults to the first item (i.e., Experiment) if a type wasn't selected.
The user must select the type to edit from the drop down list. The input field next to the Search button accepts the search criteria.
The search is performed in the following order:
accession number (ac)
short label
So, it is faster to search by an accession number than by a shortlabel.
You can accept the default search value (*) by simply clicking on the search button. This pratice is discouraged strongly as it may retrieve a large number of records from the database for some types (i.e., Interaction). Instead, you should use more restrictive filtering such as EBI-3* to retrieve a subset of records.
Fo faster response, always prefer a restrictive search criteria.
An example for a successful search:
The 'AC link' (see above) links the editor with the search application. The following figure shows the result of clicking on EBI-39 link.
The 'shortlabel link', takes you to the appropriate edit screen. In this example, 'go' entry will be opened in the CV editor (see below, Cv Editors, for more on CV editor).
Alternatively, you can go to the edit screen by searching for EBI-39 or 'go' alone.
A message will be displayed if a search fails to find any matching records.
The create button creates a record for the selected IntAct type. As with the search, it is important to select the appropriate type before clicking on the create button. The following screen shows the result of creating a new CvDatabase record.
The current edit type is appended to the main heading (CvDatabase) as shown above. All the drop down list items (topic, database and reference qualifier) are shown in their shortlabels. Except for the shortlabel, all other fields are optional. To distinguish between required and optional fields, required fields are shown in a different background colour. These fields are validated when the user selects a button (i.e., Add Annotation, Save etc) on the page.
All shortlabels should be one to twenty characters from the character set blank, 0..9, a-z, : ',' (colon), '_' (underscore) and '-' (hyphen). A dialog box similar to the following will appear for a failure to adhere to this syntax. Short labels are unique for all the editors apart for the Feature editor. The editor by default computes a unique shortlabel from a given value. For example, if 'abc' arleay exists on the database, giving 'abc' as a short label defaults to abc-1. ADD THE link to the curation manual
Submitting the form without entering a syntactically valid name could result in a server side validation if JavaScript is disabled in the client browser. The error response from the server is shown under the shortlabel (Note: this error only appears if Javascript is disabled in the browser).
Although both validations are similar in nature, they serve two different purposes. The first validation is performed on the client side (browser) and hence faster of the two. However, the browser must be enabled to accept Javascript for it to work (no dialog window if Javascript is not enabled). This is the preferred validation as it saves extra step in communicating with the server. Alternatively, the other validation is not dependent on Javascript and hence works on any browser.
However, some editor components such as Experiment and Interaction editors rely on Javascript and they wouldn't work correctly if Javascript is disabled. You will have then to enable Javascript in order to get the Editor to work correctly.
Annotations are added by clicking on the Add Annotation button in the Annotation section. Associated with each Annotation is a topic which is one of CvTopics available in the database. An error message is displayed when adding an annotation without selecting a type from the drop down list first.
The editing of an annotation is similar to adding a new Annotation except for topic and description are already set to their existing values. The annotations in the editing mode are shown in a different color to distinguish them from non editing annotations.
You cannot save the form if an annotation is in 'edit' mode. In this case, you must either save or delete it first.
Edit one annotation at a time as there is no way to save a group of annotations in a single button click.
Similar to Annotations, Crossreferences are added by clicking on the Add Crossreference button in the Crossreference section. The database drop list consists of names for CvDatabase items from the IntAct database and the reference qualifier consists of names for CvXrefQualifier.
As with annotations, the values from drop down lists must be selected prior to adding a crossreference. Editing an existing Crossreference is similar to adding a new one except for existing values are shown instead of empty values.
Any changes to the form are not saved until the form is submitted. So for a new IntAct type, a record is not created on the database until the Submit or Save & Continue button is clicked and the server reports no errors.
Save your work periodically by selecting Save & Continue. This avoids the danger of loosing your data due to an extended period of inactivity (session timing out).
Editing an existing record is similar to the above except the form is populated with existing data. As shown below, the name and full name already have their existing values.
Since Cv editor layout is common to all the other editors, only the differences are shown for them.
The biosource editor uses the Newt server to auto-complete the short label and the full name from a given NCBI taxid.
The Host Organism is the organism the experiment has been performed in. Example: If the interaction of Human proteins expressed in E.coli has been studied in Yeast, the Host Organism would be Yeast. The Interaction Detection describes the method which has been used to detect the interaction, e.g. yeast two hybrid. The Participant Detection describes the method which has been used to detect the participants (proteins) involved in the interaction, e.g. peptide mass fingerprinting.
This section describes Experiments already part of the current Interaction. The area below holds experiments not yet added to the Interaction as shown below.
Select Add button to add an experiment or Hide to remove from the collection. Duplicate experiments are not allowed.
This section lists all the Proteins participating in the current Interaction. For a new Interaction, this section is empty. To add a Protein, you must search for existing Proteins first by providing appropriate values for search fields. Only the most specific value is taken into consideration if multiple values are provided for search. Since IntAct AC is the most specific, other search values are ignored if a value was specified for IntAct AC.
If a search is performed by UniProt accession number (SP AC), and no matching protein is found, the editor will access an external server (by default the EBI SRS server), to retrieve the corresponding protein.
The orange colour bar on the left identfies new Proteins not yet added to the Interaction. The first Protein is already part of the Interaction and hence for absence of the color bar next to it. These 'color coded' Proteins do not form part of the current Interaction until the user save them either by selecting 'Save' or 'Save & Continue' button.
Any errors in adding Proteins are shown red colour as shown below.
This section lists all the Features participating in the current Interaction. A Feature can be added or edited by selecting 'Add Feature' and 'Edit Feature' button respectively. The 'Edit Feature' only appears if there is a Feature attached to the Protein.
A Feature must contain at least a single Range and hence Ranges section is shown in 'required field' colour. The following figure shows a Feature with multiple Ranges.
The 'Create Undefined Feature' button provides an easier way to create a Feature with an undefined range. The following figure shows the result of selecting this button.
However, you still need to select the CvFeatureType before submitting the form.
The 'Mutation' button switches the current view between Mutation/Normal Feature editor.
You can switch back to the Normal Feature editor at anytime (or vice versa) but you will lose data entered in the form.
The mutation editor as a result of switching from Normal to Mutation mode.
See the curation manual for the format of hotspots. Any errors in adding hotspot entries are shown in red with an error message.
There is no 'Save & Continue' button. You need to save the data by selecting the 'Submit' button.
The CvFeatureType defaults to hotspot. Ensure that the entire entry for hotspot is complete before you select the 'Submit' button.
What browsers Editor supports?
It has been tested using Mozilla (1.4 or above), Explorer (6.0), Konqueror (2.1.1 or above) and firefox (1.0 or above). With the Konqueror it has been noted that pop up windows do not get the focus (need to bring them manually). Also, the footer is almost at the top when a page does not contain much information.
Do I need a JRE installed to run the Editor?
No, you don't need Java Runtime to run the Editor as it is designed to run on thin clients (see the next question about JavaScript).
Do I need JavaScript to run the Editor?
Yes. Some editors such as Experiment or Interaction wouldn't work if Javascript is disabled. Links to search application wouldn't work as well.
I get a strange error with dispatchXXX not found?
This happens if you have disabled Javascript. Some forms use Javascript to store values for the server to check. When Javascript is disabled, the server throws an error as it can't find the parameter dispatchXXX.
Do I need to logout when I am finished?
There is no need to logout because your session will timeout if it has been inactive for 30 or more minutes. However, by explicitly logging out you are releasing the resources (good thing to do). So, we recommend explicit logouts.
Can I connect to my last session when my session expires?
No. Once your session expires you need to login again and this in turn will start a new session.
Sometimes I get an error when Enter key is pressed for a search string in the sidebar.
This behaviour was observed with Explorer and Konqueror but not with Mozilla. The simple solution is to click on Search button instead.
It hangs for a tax id in BioSource editor.
Either Newt server is not accessible or down. There is no way to get around this problem; you need to access the Newt server to do the auto-completion.
Currenlty, you have to go through Newt to get your taxid validated as well as the shortlabel and the fullname set to the BioSource.
The parameter to search for Proteins given as name is ignored when a value is provided for Intact Ac in the Interaction editor.
By default, IntAct AC is the most specific and it is followed by SP AC and finally the shortlabel. Given two values for name and IntAct AC, the latter is always given the priority.
In the interaction form, is there a way to save or delete all Proteins in one single click?
Not at the moment. We may add this behaviour later.
The focus seems to be lost (can't enter or select an item in the editor).
This is most likely due to the search popup having the focus. Close the search popup window to regain the focus.
HierarchView is a web based application which allow to visualise interaction networks contained in IntAct.
This includes :
Query interface: to select the set of Interactors from which the interaction network is built,
Visualising an interaction network as a two dimensional graph,
Visualisation of a protein's context (using the Search application ),
Performing action by clicking on a protein of the displayed network, to
Center the view,
Extend the view,
Displaying GO terms of all proteins from which the interaction network is built,
Displaying the GO hierarchy of a selected GO term
Highlighting all proteins annotated by a specific GO term (selected by the user)
The graphical user interface integrates:
a sidebar
the basic sidebar :
Some components of the sidebar are always visible whatever the state of the application.
This includes:
on the top, the query interface.
on the bottom, a set of IntAct related links.
the advanced sidebar : After loading a first interaction network, more features are available in the sidebar :
below the query interface, the Graph menu which allows to expand and contract the current interaction network,
above the link section, the mouse-click behaviour section which allows the user to switch the mouse-click behaviour either to center the view or add a new network.
a content frame
header : specifies from which protein(s) the current interaction network is built as well as the number of nodes and edges. If needed, the selected GO term used for the highlight is displayed.
protein interaction network : a clickable image representing the requested interaction network.
highlight top panel : a list of all GO terms associated with proteins in the currently displayed interaction network.
highlight bottom panel : After selecting one of the GO term displayed in the top right frame, the related GO hierarchy is displayed, allowing the user to perform a highlight by selecting the GO term of the hierarchy.
click the image to enlarge
It is a graphical way of representing a protein protein interaction network as a two dimensional graph structure. Within that graph, the nodes represent proteins and the edges represent interactions.
The entry point of an interaction network is an Interactor (either Protein or Interaction ) around which we will look for all Interactors within a specified threshold called depth. A depth 1 would be all direct Interactors of the selected protein.
Type in the Interactor form either a protein name or accession number and click the search button to display the related interaction network. You are free to type a comma separated list of proteins in order to display all of them in one go.
The visualization systems shows all specified proteins with a bold font. As soon as the interaction network is displayed, the user interface is changing slightly to offer more interactivity.
When querying IntAct to display an interaction network, if the query is ambiguous (e.g. the query snu* could describes several proteins such as snu66, snu13...), you will be automatically forwarded to the search application where you will be able to select the targeted protein(s).
When adding an interaction network, a new one is generated according to the user's wishes and then merged with the current one.
There are two ways of adding additional interactors to the displayed interaction network:
Type in the Interactor form either a protein name or AC and click the add button. You are free to type a comma separated list of protein in order to display all of them in one go.
If the protein of interest is available in the current interaction network, you can switch the mouse-click (sidebar) behaviour to add a network then click on the wanted protein.
In order to navigate in the interaction network, you can decide to change the current central protein. To do so, switch the mouse-click (sidebar) behaviour to center the view , then, click on the wanted protein. The current interaction network will be reloaded as the interaction network of the selected protein.
Bear in mind that it would have had the same effect to type the name or accession number of the protein in the Interactor form and click on the search button.
In order to improve the readability and the loading time, the default depth of an interaction network has been set relatively low. Nevertheless you can increase that parameter in order to expand the current interaction network by clicking the expand button in the sidebar. Bear in mind that there is a minimum and maximum depth, this implies the expand ( contract ) button disappears when the maximum (minimum) depth is reached.
After loading an interaction network, a list of GO terms specific to the set of selected proteins is displayed in the top right frame of hierarchView. By clicking on one of them, the related GO hierarchy appears in the bottom right frame (powered by QuickGo ). If a single GO term is found, the hierarchy is displayed automatically. Now you can select one of the displayed GO terms of the hierarchy in order to highlight in the interaction network all proteins annotated with that GO term in IntAct. These proteins will appear with a differently colored label.
In the displayed hierarchy, the lower GO term is the more specific, and the higher you go, the more generic the GO terms become. Bear in mind that when selecting a GO term in the displayed hierarchy the highlight is done with a set of GO terms including the selected one and all its children (i.e. until the most specific).
click the image to enlarge
After loading an interaction network, you can request to download its representation in PSI MI XML format. To do so, you have to click on the Download button of the PSI-XML section and a new window will appear in which the XML content will be displayed. After the data are fully loaded you can save that content on your hard disk.
Note to Netscape's users : You may have to right-click and select view source in order to display the XML code.
You can then, for instance, load the downloaded data in an external tool for further analysis.
You can find a list of the tools supporting the PSI MI XML format here in the Tools section.
MiNe is a web based application which computes the minimal connecting network for a given set of proteins if possible.
A minimal network is a sub network of an interaction network which has to fulfill the following points:
it has to contain all wanted proteins
the sum of the weight of the edges has to be minimal.
The weight of the edges can be either different or identical (e.g. weight 1) - then the minimal connecting network is actually the network with the minimal number of nodes
This includes :
Query interface: to select the set of Interactors from which the minimal network is computed,
Computation of the minimal connecting network,
Forwarding to HierarchView to visualise the network
Type in the Interactor form either a protein name or accession number and click the Find network button to get the related minimal connecting network. You are free to type a comma separated list of proteins in order to display all of them in one go.
As search phrases can be used:
IntAct Ac: EBI-44444
Gene names: lsm7
UniProtKB Ac: Q08162
UniProtKB Id: rr44_yeast
InterPro Ac: IPR001900
GO Id: GO:0000176
If your search returns an ambiguous result all found proteins for every search phrase are shown on this page.
An ambiguous result occurs when you search for either an Interaction or an Experiment or at least one search phrase returns more than one protein.
To proceed you have to select the proteins from which you want to compute the minimal connecting network by activating the checkboxes related to the proteins.
In this textbox you can enter an additional search query that will be used to complement the set of proteins currently shown on the page.
If you want to add search phrases to your selection type a protein or an accession number or a comma seperated list into this field
If you want to search for the phrases instead of the selection make sure to deselect all proteins found by the previous search.
Please be aware of the search limit of seven proteins !
This application exports a graph as PSI MI Format (MIF). The user can access this using the SOAP protocol as a WebService, Servlet or direct.
The URL to access the web service is the following: http://server.domain[:port]/intact/graph2mif
You can replace server.domain[:port] by www.ebi.ac.uk
For validation: Just call the URL above within a browser. It should displays a basic web form which allows to fill in the parameters of your query.
There are two ways to request a MIF:
Soap: Using a SOAPClient. The only method you have to call is http://server.domain:port/intact/graph2mif/soap/getMIF(ac,depth,striftmif) .
Direct URL call: http://server.domain:port/intact/graph2mif/getXML?ac= Ac &depth= Integer &strict= (true|false)
Depending on the way you would like to access the data you call the soap-method getMIF() or directly the URL like mentioned above. Both of them have three Arguments ac, depth, strictmif A graph will be retrieved (representing a protein protein interaction network) starting with an interactor of ac and expanded to depth of depth striftmif is a Boolean. When set to true, a graph in PSI MI XML format will only be generated if the data allows to provide all required PSI MI attributes. Otherwise a exception is thrown. When set to false, the generated graph will still be in PSI MI format, but might lack some mandatory elements.
The resulting graph will be returned in PSI MI XML as a formated XML-String.
The example java webservice client Graph2MIFWSClient is also included in this package.
The client must know where to access the WebService, so go to the source code and change the Line with URL url = new URL("...") to your system. Afterwards you can compile it using ant client" .
Just call: java uk.ac.ebi.intact.application.graph2MIF.Graph2MIFWSClient ac depth (true|false)
to get a graph of IntAct as MIF. The result will be printed to STDOUT . Have a look at the simple source code for getting an impression of how to write your own client.
This client does not implement a WebService, it directly accesses the IntAct Database. The rest is mainly the same: java uk.ac.ebi.intact.application.graph2MIF.Graph2MIFClient ac depth (true|false)
to get a graph in PSI MI XML format. The result will be printed to STDOUT . Have also a look at the simple source code for getting an impression of how to write your own client.
For details about the mapping have a look at the annotated MIF.xsd or at the generated mapping documentation here.
For details about MIF hava a look at the homepage of the PSI project: Proteomics Standards Initiative
ProViz is a high-performance, standalone visualization system for molecular interactions. For a detailed description, please see the ProViz user manual .
Uncovering the interactome is one of the primary challenges in the post-genomic era. The topology information gained from the coverage of interaction space can shed light on the likely function and structure of proteins within the network (Vitkup et al, 2001). Here we present a list of the 'best baits' which give the highest return on experimental effort - i.e. those proteins which form 'hubs' in the interaction network. These lists are generated using the Pay-As-You-Go strategy (Lappe, M. Holm, L.(2004) Nature Biotechnology 22, pp 98 - 103) which detects and prioritises those proteins which have the highest likelihood of being hubs based on the current data within IntAct for various species. To illustrate the experimental effort which could be saved by using the strategy recommended here, take the Human interactome as an example. It is estimated that 50,000 experiments would be required to cover the entire human interactome following a purely random strategy for the selection of targets. The information gain here is close to linear for each experiment. This could be drastically reduced to less than 10,000 for 90% coverage of the entire human interactome by using the proteins listed here as baits. This would save years of experimental effort. This of course relies on the timely deposition of experimental data into the IntAct database in order that the Pay-As-You-Go algorithm should be fully uptodate and effective.
